abstract: Michael Lewis, who rose to literary stardom with "Liar's Poker," his memoir about life as a bond salesman at Salomon Brothers in the 1980s, has kept himself busy with new books, film adaptations and increasingly, a habit of making stars of his subjects. New York magazine writes that Mr. Lewis has created "a personal empire of long-form journalism, with a Warren Buffett-like collection of brands and eye for the next big thing."
